titleproper.value: Preliminary Inventory of the Kenneth Crowe Papers. <num>WAG.088</num>

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2018-06-05T16:14:51</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

p.value: Donated by Kenneth Crowe in 2002 and 2003. The accession number associated with this gift is 2002.030.

Kenneth C. Crowe, was a journalist, writing for<emph render="italic"> Newsday</emph> from 1963 until his retirement in 1999.  In his early years at<emph render="italic"> Newsday</emph> he specialized in foreign investment, and traveled widely in Europe and the Middle East.  He was part of an investigative team that won the Pulitzer Prize Gold Medal in 1970 and went on to win a long list of professional awards and honors.  From 1976 he was assigned to cover organized labor, and his columns on the subject became essential reading on the recent history of the New York-area labor movement.  Crowe's research on Ron Carey's successful campaign for the presidency of the Teamsters resulted in the publication, in 1993, of his book, <emph render="italic">Collision: How the Rank and File Took Back the Teamsters.</emph>

The collection consists largely of files of research materials compiled during the writing of Kenneth Crowe's book, <emph render="italic">Collision: How the Rank and File Took Back the Teamsters</emph> (New York, Scribners, 1993).  The material includes clippings, reports, court documents, agreements, audiotaped interviews, videotapes and notes, as well as editorial correspondence, drafts and reviews of the book.

subject.value: Labor unions -- Elections -- New York (State) -- New York.
Labor unions -- New York (State) -- New York.
